abstract.p: Letter from Gerald Schraub says E-ZPass will fail to alleviate ever-worsening traffic headaches unless certain changes are made

block.p: Contrary to assurances from highway officials that the E-ZPass rush-hour inauguration on the New Jersey Turnpike went smoothly and augurs well for the future (news article, Oct. 3), I believe that unless changes are made, backups will continue and E-ZPass will fail to alleviate the ever-worsening traffic headaches.

Contrary to assurances from highway officials that the E-ZPass rush-hour inauguration on the New Jersey Turnpike went smoothly and augurs well for the future (news article, Oct. 3), I believe that unless changes are made, backups will continue and E-ZPass will fail to alleviate the ever-worsening traffic headaches.

The New Jersey Turnpike, as well as the Garden State Parkway, must adopt the strategies that are in use at other toll collection points in New York and New Jersey: isolation of E-ZPass lanes from the cash lanes, painted lanes indicating the path to the E-ZPass booths, and signs at the approaches noting the configuration so that drivers are alerted long before the toll plaza is reached.
Without these aids, drivers will continue to jockey for lane placement, block access to the E-ZPass lanes and help sustain the current state of toll-plaza gridlock.
GERALD SCHRAUB Glen Rock, N.J., Oct. 3, 2000
